_header: Toward the end of windy February
Note:
A prose paraphrase occurs in London, British Library Cotton Vitellius A.XVI and London, College of Arms, Arundel 19; cf. 396, 6042; Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler TM 1773; Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988 TP 2056.5.
Subjects: Henry VI, entry into London, 1432; envoys; historical poems; pageants, accounts of
_description: John Lydgate, King Henry VI’s Triumphal Entry into London (1432) — seventy-six stanzas rhyme royal and 8-line Envoy

BLCottCleoCIV.First Lines:
Toward the end of wyndy ffebruarieWhan phebus whas in the ffyssh
                    coroune…
BLCottCleoCIV.Last Lines:
…Considre this that in most lowly wiseMy will were good for to
                    do you seruise
BLCottCleoCIV.Editions:
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             A Selection from the Minor Poems of Don John Lydgate.
Percy Society
         2. London: T. Richard, 1840: 2-22.

BLCottJulBII.First Lines: Towarde the ende off wyndy ffebruarieWhanne Phebus was in the ffysshe eronne…
BLCottJulBII.Last Lines: …Considre this that in moste lowly wyseMy wille were goode fforto do yow servyse
BLCottJulBII.Note:
Rubric “envoye” between last line and the 8-line envoy (f. 100v). 76 stanzas rhyme royal and 8-line envoy.  Ends on 100v not 101v as listed in Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943.
BLCottJulBII.Attributed Title: Ordenaunces ffor the kyng made in the entere off London (rubric in right margin beside first line, f. 89)

             Lyric Forms from France.

MacCracken,  Henry Noble,

EETS

MacCracken,  Henry Noble. 
             “King Henry’s Triumphal Entry into London: Lydgate’s Poem
                and Carpenter’s Letter.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         126 (1911): 75-102: 75-97 (roundel only).

BLHar565.First Lines: Towardþe ende of wyndy ffebruarieWhanne Phebus was in þe fyssh ronne…
BLHar565.Last Lines: …Considere þis þat in þe moost lowly wyseMy will were goodfor to do seruyse
BLHar565.Attributed Title: Here endith þe makyng of þe comynge of þe kyng out of ffraunce to London (f. 124)

Guildhall3313.First Lines:
Toward the ende of wyndy ffebruaryWhan Phebus was in the ffyssh
                    eronne…
Guildhall3313.Last Lines:
…Considre this that in lowly wyseMy wille were good forto do
                    you seruyse

The ordenaunces made in the Citee of londone a yenst the comyng of the kyng
